column2: Bot-ne introduces themselves and shows notebook UI

column3: Dialogue
Green greetings to ya! I'm BOT-NE, the cutest lab assistant ever made!
I've got your lab table all set up. You remembered your notebook, right?
column4: Gameplay: flashing UI prompt to open and close notebook

column2: Bot-ne reinforces notetaking, shows the first plant

column3: Dialogue
Remember, scientists take notes about everything they observe.
Like how I'm just the pluckiest little bot you've ever seen!
Jokes aside, lets get to the real science. Come see the first plant.
Dialogue
This my friend zea mays. She thinks it's corny when I use her full name.
She's trying to talk to you, but I take it you don't speak plant, right?
Luckily, I've got the next best thing. Wrap your twigs around this.
column4: Gameplay: UI element flashes, players can control scanner. Hint sequence 1.a plays

column3: Dialogue

column1: Once the last hint of hints 1.a plays
column3: Zea is telling us she wants something.
To find out what, we've got to the scientific method.
Try adding these chemicals. See if the signals change.
column4: Gameplay: player can access chemical tray. Hint sequence 1.b plays

column3: Dialogue

column1: Once correct hint chemical hint of hint 1.b plays
column3: Now that's one vivacious corn plant!
Scan zea mays again, notice anything?
column4: Gameplay:player scans plant again, then next dialogue plays

column3: When plants don't need nitrogen, they stop producing this signal
That's called a negative signal. It says when something's missing.
What are you waiting for? Write that down! This is real science!
column4: Gameplay: UI journal element flashes, players open notebook which contains nitrogen signal rule

column3: Dialogue
You've completed your first experiment! Congrats, seedling!
Now you know that that red signal is plant talk for "nitrogen, please!"
Let's go see what some of the other plants are saying. Bet it's real sappy.
Dialogue
Solanum lycopersicum. They're a little bashful, always blushing.
What are they saying they need?
column4: Gameplay: player scans and can add chemicals.

column2: Bot-ne points out that there are two signals

column3: Dialogue

column1: Player tries to add just nitrogen a few times unsuccessfully.
column3: This tomato does need nitrogen, but the signal's not changing.
This means the plant can't absorb nitrogen. Yet.
Hmm, maybe the plant needs something else first?
column6: Is Iron a positive or negative signal? In the current alpha version it's positive so the second plant is _less_ chatty because it's missing the iron symbol. So it would be more like "I feel like something's missing here! See, there's that other signal from your lab notebook!"

column3: Dialogue
Wow, a new signal appeared!
Don't worry, that just means this is a positive signal.
The tomato is saying "I have enough iron".
You know the drill. Notebook! For science!
column4: Gameplay: notebook UI flashes, new entry added.

column3: Dialogue
I'm impressed, seedling! This is way above intern-level stuff.
The tomato was communicating with themselves.
They needed iron before they could absorb nitrogen.
The tomato waited for the "I have iron" signal.
Only then did they absorb the nitrogen you gave it.
And then stopped saying "I don't have nitrogen".
So, plant signals can be interdependent.
Which is science talk for "plants talk to themselves"! Notebook!
column4: Gameplay: notebook UI flashes, new entry added.

column3: Dialogue
Time to prove that you're ready to bloom to full-flowered scientist.
This is A. thanalia, or thale cress. He's a bit of a star around here.
Take a look. What's he gabbing about this time?
Dialogue
Celebrities, am I right? They think they're the center of the greenhouse.
Figure out what this needy plant wants.
Careful, no nitrogen or iron for this prima flora. He's already got a potfull.
Use those photoreceptors to take a good peep at the chemical tags.
column4: Gameplay: Player briefly gains access to the chemical wheel, can tap through 2-3 to see that they have new labels

column2: Bot-ne introduces the open ended challenge

column3: Dialogue
Unfortunately, we only have 3 thale cress plants in the greenhouse.
This is where you prove yourself as a scientist.
You'll get your official botanist rating based on how the plants fare.
Whatever you do, make sure we still have at least one plant by the end!
column4: Gameplay: player starts to figure out what to give the plant.

column3: Dialogue

column1: if player doesn't kill a single plant
column3: Seedling, you blew my pods off!
Congratulations! You're now a Lead Plant Whisperer!
column4: Gameplay: ID card flashes on screen with prompt to go to end screen.

column3: Dialogue

column1: if player kills only one plant
column3: Mistakes are like fertilizer for discovery.
Well done, seedling! You're officially an Associate Botany Wiz.
column4: Gameplay: ID card flashes on screen with prompt to go to end screen.

column3: Dialogue
Trimming it a little close. Good on you for figuring it out in the end!
Solid effort! I name you Junior Green Technician.
column4: Gameplay: ID card flashes on screen with prompt to go to end screen.

column3: Dialogue
Oh pests and pustules, there goes our last thale cress!
It's ok, seedling, they're very common in the wild. We'll find more.
He needed Magnesium, then Phosphorus, then Calcium.
column4: Gameplay: notebook UI flashes and populates with update

column3: We'll keep you at Plant Talk Intern for now. Come back tomorrow!
column4: Gameplay: ID card flashes on screen with prompt to go to end screen.
